title: Arnside Knott Circular Walk Map Route

images.title: David Grimshaw / Arnside Knott, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: View from just below Arnside Knott looking North West over River Kent estuary

images.title: Richard Webb / Arnside Knott, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Limestone screes and grassland on the south face of this rugged little hill. The Knott is known for sightings of rare butterflies like the High Brown Fritillary, making it popular with wildlife enthusiasts. At 159 metres, it’s not particularly high, but its trails provide peaceful walks with rich flora, fauna, and impressive landscapes.

images.title: Bryan Pready / Slopes below Arnside Knott, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Slopes below the Knott with the Kent estuary and Arnside railway viaduct in the distance. Arnside is a charming coastal village located on the edge of Morecambe Bay in Cumbria, England. It’s known for its picturesque views of the bay and nearby hills, especially Arnside Knott, which offers scenic hiking trails and sweeping vistas. The village has a rich history, evident in its Victorian architecture and its heritage as a former port. Visitors enjoy strolling along the Arnside Promenade, where they can observe the unique tidal bore as the sea rushes into the estuary. Arnside’s quiet cafes, local shops, and friendly atmosphere make it a delightful spot for relaxation and exploration in the heart of the Arnside and Silverdale Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty.

images.title: Colin Kinnear / Arnside Knott Trig, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The well maintained trig point on the summit

images.title: Dave Green / Arnside Viaduct from the Knott, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Arnside Viaduct from the Knott. The railway line is carried over the River Kent on a viaduct 552 yards (505 m) long, with 50 piers. It was built in 1857 and rebuilt in 1915.

images.title: roz stirman / View NE from Arnside Knott Trig Point, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: View North East from the trig point

images.title: Bob Jenkins / Footpath in Arnside Knott Woods, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Erosion of the very popular path arrears to have exposed the roots of this tree.

images.title: Richard Webb / Yew woods, Arnside Knott., via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Yew woods. Dark and ancient woodlands below the Knott

description: This popular circular walk takes you around a small, coastal hill in the Arnside and Silverdale AONB. The route runs for a distance of just under two miles with a small climb on the way. The Knott is a popular beauty spot and internationally important wildlife area. The area includes a mixture of limestone grassland, woodland, wet meadow, scree and scrub. It's also renowned for its butterflies and flowers. From the 159 metres (522 ft) high point there are fabulous views over Silverdale and the coastal estuary towards Grange over Sands, Morecambe Bay, the River Kent Estuary and the Lake District fells. There's a handy toposcope at the top which details the landmarks you can see from the summit. This circular walk starts at the car park by the hill and takes you to the viewpoint and through the woodland on public footpaths. It runs for about 1.5 miles with a little climbing on the way. You can continue your walk by picking up the Cumbria Coastal Way which starts at the nearby Milnthorpe Sands. Or you could visit the nearby Leighton Moss Nature Reserve. Also nearby is Warton Crag nature reserve with its rare butterflies and plants. Just to the south, you can follow footpaths to and enjoy a climb to the Victorian Pepperpot monument on King William's Hill.
